loc: Jelutong Tower, Central Catchment Nature Reserve, Singapore

rmk: Acknowledgements: I took this sound recording during a fieldwork as a member of the Avian Evolution Lab from the National University of Singapore. Also thanks to Laura and Ulmar for coordinating the fieldwork.
A pair seen together foraging on the ground

loc: Trail to Krung Ching Waterfall, Khao Luang National Park

rmk: Witnessed a pairof adults duetting. The birds were perched less than 50cm apart on a log, facing each other. One bird was calling facing up while swinging its neck left and right, while the other was facing the calling bird and flickering its wings (similar to the movements a begging juvenile makes, but less aggressive). They later flew to another log and continued the same process. After about 3 minutes one bird disappeared and the other bird continued foraging quietly. The foraging bird was so confiding it hopped up to within 1 metres of us, completely unperturbed by our presence. At one point it even perched at the edge of the trail.

Peninsular Malaysia (near  Simpang Pertang), Negeri Sembilan
rmk: Duet of two birds close to ground. In muddy patch of secondary forest, along stream with rattans

calling concealed in dense damp undergrowth at edge of reservoir.  adult Siberian Blue Robin female seen immediately before recording but male and 1st winter female also wintering in same spot so could be male or female.  rapid ticking with occasional single whistle note.  Thanks to a Xeno-Canto user Yeo SB I have reviewed this recording and agree with him that it is a Short-Tailed Babbler which often occurs in exactly the same spot and (I have since realised) occasionally makes this call at dusk.  There was another Siberian Blue Robin wintering here this year (2020) and during numerous encounters we only heard a simple 'tick' call
